subject: RE: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Engineering (at least for chip design) has the concept of testability, and electronic designs definitely have features (e.g., extra inputs and outputs)
messageBody:
> From: Morris, Chris [mailto:ChrisM@...]
> ...
>
>
> > > What's wrong with forcing production code to change only to
> > make it more
> > > testable?
> >
> > I think that a testing tool can suggest you to change your code but
> > shouldn't force you to do it. ....
>
> .... But
> I do think that I as a programmer should be willing to make changes in
> production code for the sake of testability.

Engineering (at least for chip design) has the concept of testability,
and electronic designs definitely have features (e.g., extra inputs and
outputs) that are there only to make things testable. There's also the
concepts of controllability and observability.

Of course, in software, we could always(?) use debuggers and emulators
to get controllability and observability, but sometimes changes to
enhance testability are reasonable.


Daniel
